image.altText: Bottles or canisters labelled as "pepper spray" on a table

props.synopsis: The NT is set to join WA in allowing residents to carry pepper spray, in a trial the government says will improve public safety and give people "lawful tools to protect themselves".

title.children: NT to allow public to carry pepper spray 'to protect themselves'

image.altText: A man wearing police uniform speaking in a press briefing room.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's acting police commissioner clarifies why police believe the investigation into Kumanjayi White's death should not be outsourced to an external body.

title.children: NT police boss faces political questioning over Kumanjayi White death probe

image.altText: The outside of the NAAJA building in Darwin.

props.synopsis: Aboriginal legal service NAAJA is calling for an "emergency intervention" to "de-escalate" tensions in the Northern Territory's justice system, following two deaths of Aboriginal men in police custody in less than a fortnight.

title.children: Legal service urges 'emergency intervention' after two NT deaths in custody

image.altText: Crew walk away uninjured from spectacular Finke Desert Race crash

props.synopsis: A trophy truck driver and his navigator are "surprisingly well" after becoming airborne before a spectacular, cartwheeling crash during the Finke Desert Race.

title.children: Desert racers unscathed as wild 160kph crash caught on camera

image.altText: Japanese navy boss stands in front of frigate and smiles

props.synopsis: The Mogami-class frigate's arrival in Darwin comes as Japan competes with Germany to secure a $10 billion Australian defence contract.

title.children: Mogami-class frigate docks in Darwin as Japan pushes for $10bn contract

image.altText: A man sits with his hand covering his mouth at a meeting.

props.synopsis: With one mine still temporarily shut down and another smelter about to pause its operations, GFG Alliance workers across Australia are being left in limbo as Sanjeev Gupta's business woes continue.

title.children: Billionaire's business woes see hundreds of Australian workers sent home

image.altText: A woman smiles in front of a dark backdrop

props.synopsis: Northern Territory federal MP Marion Scrymgour slams current and former governments for "taking their eye off the ball" regarding Aboriginal deaths in custody, while a grieving grandfather tells police to "get off our backs".

title.children: MP slams governments for lack of leadership over black deaths in custody

image.altText: An aerial view of the township of Wadeye (Port Keats).

props.synopsis: A man who died in police custody at a Darwin hospital on Saturday has been remembered as a "great visionary and educator" as the remote community of Wadeye mourns his loss.

title.children: Senior Wadeye elder identified as latest NT death in custody

image.altText: A saltwater crocodile wading into a river, with the sandy bank in the background.

props.synopsis: Katter's Australian Party is proposing new legislation that would allow crocodile culls and safari style hunting trips in Queensland. That bill is currently before a parliamentary inquiry.

title.children: Farmers raise concerns at parliamentary inquiry over increasing croc numbers

image.altText: A team of people cheering as they float on a boat decorated with empty beer cans.

props.synopsis: The Down Under Safari Pirates have won the 51st Darwin Beer Can Regatta at Mindil Beach with a boat made from plastic drums and empty beer cans.

title.children: Thousands turn out to cheer on homemade boats at Darwin Beer Can Regatta

image.altText: A man unloads a large item from a crane.

props.synopsis: Indigenous employment rules have been dropped from two-thirds of Commonwealth contracts, meaning $70 billion worth of contracts did not have to hire a minimum number of Indigenous people or use Indigenous businesses.

title.children: Indigenous employment rules dropped from most Commonwealth contracts

image.altText: a man in a high-vis jacket loading cattle from a truck to a ship.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of claimants seeking compensation are considering an appeal, after the federal court found the 2011 live export ban did not impact export quotas "in any material way".

title.children: Court downplays scale of cattle industry losses after live export ban

image.altText: A row of men in military wear hold transparent shields that say 'California National Guard'.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump says the National Guard will leave Los Angeles "when there's no danger" as ICE intensifies deportation crackdown. Follow live.

title.children: Curfew declared in downtown LA as mayor says city does not need 'armies'

image.altText: Men stand in a line in front of Chinese and US flags.

props.synopsis: The US and China have agreed in principle on a framework to carry out an agreement they reached on resolving their trade disputes last month.

title.children: US and China agree on a framework to resolve their trade disputes

image.altText: Austrian police officers standing at a Graz school

props.synopsis: At least 11 people have died in Austria's deadliest mass shooting in recent history. Here's what we know about how the tragedy unfolded.

title.children: What we know so far about the Austrian school shooting

image.altText: Picture of Australian one dollar coins stacked on top of note currency

props.synopsis: With little fanfare and a deadline fast approaching, millions of people may slip through the cracks.

title.children: Millions of Australians could miss out on refunds from financial misconduct

image.altText: People exit a commercial airliner onto the tarmac at an airport beneath a clear sky.

props.synopsis: Flights between Broome in WA's north and Singapore will cease next month after the sudden announcement by Qantas that Jetstar Asia will cease to operate.

title.children: Jetstar Asia closure marks end of Broome-Singapore route

image.altText: A silver-bearded man in a blue shirt stands in front of a driveway through pine trees.

props.synopsis: It was meant to be a run-of-the-mill auction with only one interested party, but then locals say nefarious actors turned up and prices soared.

title.children: Peter thought he owned his driveway until it was listed for auction

image.altText: us president donald trump sits in front of howard lutnick in the oval office

props.synopsis: Australian shares gain moderately after US and Chinese officials announce a "framework" deal to restore the flow of key products between the two countries. Follow live.

title.children: ASX edges up in muted reaction to US-China 'handshake deal'

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ANZ-Roy Morgan consumer confidence rises a touch
US commerce secretary says rare earths and magnets expected to flow soon
ASX on the rise amid muted reaction to 'handshake deal'

image.altText: Two middle aged men with short hair stand side by side as they pose for a photo.

props.synopsis: After being captured by Russia, two prisoners of war were "beaten" and "humiliated" — but not broken. Six months after their release, they are sharing their stories.

title.children: Two men captured in Ukraine reveal what goes on inside Russian prisons

image.altText: A a look inside terminal at Western Sydney Airport

props.synopsis: Despite Western Sydney International Airport being on track to open in late 2026, clarity on two stumbling blocks remain up in the air.

title.children: First look inside Australia's newest international airport as issues remain

image.altText: Three workers, one in white overalls and the others in orange and yellow high vis, look at a gap in the road with metal spikes.

props.synopsis: One lane of traffic has reopened on the Princes Freeway after a truck rollover damaged cars and left commuters stuck in traffic for hours.

title.children: Hours-long traffic delays in Melbourne's west as crews inspect road damage

image.altText: Mat Ryan is hugged by Milos Degenek

props.synopsis: The keeper said he felt like he had played his final Socceroos match when he was left out of the starting XI late last year. Now he's celebrated his 100th international with a fine penalty stop as Australia progressed to the FIFA World Cup.

title.children: Timeless Mat Ryan caps 100th game with fine penalty save

image.altText: A cartoon shows four characters pointing various weapons in a game scenario at something out of frame

props.synopsis: Police are warning Hong Kong residents against downloading the Reversed Front: Bonfire mobile game, saying those who have installed the app may be seen as possessing a publication with seditious intent.

title.children: Hong Kong police say mobile phone game violates security law

image.altText: Silhouette of a short-haired girl, in baggy clothes, standing in front of a window looking off to the side

props.synopsis: Tasmania's government is failing to keep children safe through its continued practice of placing them in adult prison watch-houses, a new report says.

title.children: Girls in adult watch-houses subjected to searches by male staff, report finds

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

props.synopsis: With the end of the financial year approaching, tax agents say it is a good time to look at maximising your super, which might provide some tax benefits too.

title.children: How to boost your super in a tax-effective way

image.altText: A person holds a smartphone. The screen shows an avatar of an AI companion.

props.synopsis: AI-powered friends and partners can fight loneliness, but they can also supercharge isolation. So how can companion apps be made safer?

title.children: How safe are AI companions? Experts say app developers are falling short

image.altText: An illustration of army vehicles driving ashore from ferry-type green craft.

props.synopsis: Growing concern surrounds delays to a Western Australian project to build army water landing craft, amid fears other shipbuilding efforts could also be disrupted.

title.children: Uncertainty and delays loom over West Australian naval shipyard project

image.altText: Sunshine Coast Mayor Rosanna Natoli stands in a green suit at a press conference held in Nambour.

props.synopsis: Internal and external reviews are underway after the Sunshine Coast Council revealed five years of financial errors, in the order of $30 million, that could leave a $20 million hole in its budget.

title.children: Sunshine Coast Council reveals $30m accounting error ahead of budget

image.altText: A bald man with a white beard and red top sits at a table.

props.synopsis: John planned to live out his days at a caravan park but was issued an eviction notice after nearly two years. He took the case to the Supreme Court which has ruled the eviction attempt "invalid and of no effect".

title.children: Eviction notice for van park resident ruled invalid, as judge blasts 'oppression'

image.altText: A woman smiles while she holds up some fabric.

props.synopsis: Regional fashion designers who source their fabrics from op shops, dead stock, and even off the sheep's back say they offer a more sustainable alternative to fast fashion.

title.children: Small designers struggle to compete in flooded fast-fashion market

image.altText: Proxy Sam Matti

props.synopsis: New research shows almost half of refugees previously working as managers and professionals are, 10 years later, still experiencing what's known as an "occupational downgrade".

title.children: The 'occupational downgrade' hurting almost half of all skilled refugees

image.altText: Two men look to each other whilst standing in a group

props.synopsis: The uncertainty in Tasmanian politics will go on for at least a few more days, with a decision by the state governor about whether to grant a request for a state election deferred until Friday.

title.children: A $2m typo, a trip to the governor and a call for time: Tasmania's election limbo

image.altText: A best before sticker on the bottom of a jar of preserved blueberries.

props.synopsis: Australian households could be tossing perfectly good food away because of unclear best before and use-by dates.

title.children: Australians are throwing out $2,500 worth of food before it goes off

image.altText: Kurt Mann passes the ball to his left during a Maroons training session.

props.synopsis: Kurt Mann is one of the NRL's toughest players and it all goes back to the day he played a rugby league match and ran a cross-country with turmeric powder stuffed up his nose.

title.children: How a nose full of turmeric gave a glimpse of a Maroons debutant's toughness
